results.title: The Race to reshape cars
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Shaken by the recent fuel crisis the notoriously conservative motor industry is at last giving serious attention to the question of fuel economy. The answer they believe lies in body shapes. Horizon looks at some recent alternatives to conventional shapes from Britain, Germany and Italy.

results.title: Portrait of a poison
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
The chemical revolution since World War II has introduced a new family of poisons- man-made, invisible, powerful, little understood, totally useless but totally devastating. The most deadly of these is dioxin, a by-product in the manufacture of certain herbicides such as Agent Orange and 245T. Narrated by Paul Vaughan.

results.title: The Planets
results.creator_credit: Edward Goldwyn and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Outlines the research and development of NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the USA over the 13 years from 1961-1974. The significant findings of space missions and the techniques used to analyse information are dealt with. Scientists and astronauts involved discuss space exploration, the origins of the planets and the solar system. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Pedal power
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A new look at the self-propelled bicycle, the most effective known way of translating energy into motion. Traces the development of the bicycle and examines the bicycle’s possible role in the modern transport scene in the light of the present world fuel crisis.

results.title: Painting by numbers (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A program about the history and development of computer graphics and the way that artists and industrialists are exploring the potential of this ‘new’ technique. Includes interviews with film director George Lucas about film-making applications, the engineer who invented the first video game and uses in training airline pilots. Narrated by Paul Vaughan. Music by Paddy Kingsland. Written by Alec Nisbett.

results.title: Outbreak: the microbe masters the mould
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, David Dugan and Oliver Morse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Golden Staph is an organism which has developed various strains that are resistant to most of the antibiotics used today. This documentary looks at the very serious problems that resulted from an outbreak of this virulent organism at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, in 1981, and the stringent methods which were used to control the spread of infection.

results.title: The Other way
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents the ideas of E.F. Schumacher, a British economist who is deeply concerned with dwindling fuel supplies, myths about modern technology, and the loss of human worth in 20th-century consumer production. Emphasises his idea that many modern machines use too much energy and that there is a need to develop an intermediate technology of machines that consume less energy. Commentary by Ian Holm.

results.creator_credit: Edward Goldwyn and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Examines the role of the computer in today’s society. Discusses the development and manufacturing of the silicon chip- or microprocessor- which will totally revolutionise our way of life. Shows changes which have already occurred in the factory, office, farm and shop and explains the implications for future societies.

results.title: Moving still
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Uses archival material to show the development of early photography, from the first photograph of 1827 through to the first slow motion study in 1901. Also illustrates how scientists, designers and engineers use time-lapse cameras to cheat time; to look beyond our human perceptions; and to study the world of high and low-speed activity.

results.title: The Mondragon experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Mondragon in the Basque region of Spain, is an industrial town where more than 80 factories are co-operatively owned by the workers. All this has been created with scant help from a suspicious government and no funds from stock-market investors. It has run successfully for twenty-five years. The workers run the factories and appoint the managers, run their own bank, technical college and research laboratories. In Britain, workers and management have been at loggerheads since the Industrial Revolution. Examines the feasability of Britain following the same road to prosperity. Narrated by Alexander John
